UHLER ON THE ATHLETIC BOARD

BOB LAYFIELD IS NOT IMPROVED

GETTYSBURG TIES VARSITY

Seniors Elect Him Honorary President
at Meeting Friday —Hullabaloo Benefits Planned by Committee.

Track Man Is Chosen Senior Delegate
to Succeed Baker—Appointments
of Team Advisers Ratified.

Injured Quarterback Has Shown No Signs
of Betterment—Is Bright in Room
Filled With Flowers.

• Claude Uhler was selected senior
delegate to the Athletic Board at
its meeting Monday to fill the vacancy made by the resignation of
William A. Baker, Jr.
A rule of the Student Council
prohibits membership on the Athletic Board and the Student Council at the same time, and as Baker
was elected to both, it was necessary for him to retire from one of
the positions. He chose to serve
the Student Council, and was elected its president. His resignation
from the Athletic Board was accepted Monday, and Uhler was
chosen to take his place.
Advisers for the spring teams
were also officially chosen at the
meeting. The Board ratified the
selections of the following advisers:
For Baseball—Dr. R. B. Roulston and Mr. Dobbin.
For Track—Theodore E. Straus
and J. England.
For Lacrosse—William Schmeisser. Another delegate to be chosen.
The advisers were elected by
committees composed of the managers and captains of the teams,
with Graduate Manager G. E.
Dorsey serving as the third member of each committee.
Assistant managers for spring
teams were also selected. The
Board, however, was disappointed
at the small number of applications

The condition of Bob Layfield,
the 'Varsity quarterback, who was
injured in the Lehigh game Saturday a week ago, has not improved.
He is a critical condition, and while
the surgeons at Johns Hopkins Hospital hope he may recover, they are
not optimistic over his condition.
His backbone is fractured, and an
operation to relieve resulting pressure on the spinal cord is impossible. Layfield is paralyzed from
the neck down.
The case is very similar to that
of Earl Wilson, the Naval Academy player, whose injury several
years ago attracted national interest
because of his prominence as a
player and the fact that an injury
resulting from football had never
before been so serious.
Bob Layfield, in spite of his condition, is bright, and is fighting hard
to recover. His room ill the hospital is filled with flowers—the
tributes having come from Dean
Griffin, the Lehigh football team,
the freshman and sophomore classes
and other societies and individuals
who are concerned about his case.
President Frank J. Goodnow, of
Hopkins; President Henry S.
Drinker, of Lehigh, and Dean Griffin have called to express their sympathy, but only a few friends have
been admitted to his room. President Drinker came from South
Bethlehem, Pa., where Layfield was
injured, especially to see Mr. and
Mrs. W. R. Layfield, the parents of
the player.
At a special meeting of the Athletic Board last week he was awarded an honorary "H," and the emblem sewed on a sweater was taken
to him by Ben Tappan. He appreciated the award more than anything that has been sent. It represents the goal he was seeking to
reach by his playing with the 'Varsity eleven.
The player was graduated from
Friends' School in Wilmington,
Del., last June. He decided to
study medicine at Johns Hopkins,
and to get the proper preparation
came to the University to take the
degree of bachelor of arts. This
was his freshman year.
At the Wilmington school he was
an all-around athlete in spite of
his light weight. He played end on
the football team, was a basketball
star, and ran for the track team.
A letter from Principal Norris, of
Friends' School, to THE NEws-LETT1;11, says that he was one of the
school's best students and athletes,
and that he was an "exemplary
young man."

Dr. John Calvin French, associate professor of English, was elected honorary president of the senior
class at the third meeting of the
year, held on Friday. He was
chosen on the third ballot. A large
number of candidates were nominated, but scattered votes prevented
the formation of a majority on the
earlier ballots.
Dr. French was notified that the
seniors had paid him the highest
honor in their gift by a committee
Friday afternoon. He expressed
his appreciation and asked to be
called upon for any service the class
may need of him.
President Joseph T. Bartlett, Jr..,
was empowered by the class to appoint a committee to arrange benefits for the Hullabaloo. He chose
a committee consisting of George
Hall, chairman; Rush W. Smith
and Joel Hutzler. These men will
co-operate with Business Manager
Spencer in securing funds for the
..class book.
Mr. Spencer made a short speech
on the Hullabaloo in which he notified the men that all pictures intended for the book should be taken
before Christmas. Individual photographs not made before then will
not find a place in the book unless
special arrangement is made. He
also made his usual appeal for the
payment of class dues.

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.

Hopkins was unable to defeat
Gettysburg on Saturday, but all
things considered, the team played
commendable football. The improvement in general team play
over that displayed in previous
games was distinctly encouraging.
Individually the men played with
more assurance and for the first
time this season we saw indications
of concerted efforts, both on attack
and defence. The improvement was
most gratifying in view of the
many enforced changes in the lineup.
When coaches are reduced to the
necessity of making back field men
out of centre and tackle material
at a week's notice, we must not expect too much in the way of finished
execution. Much has to be done
in the involved game of today, and
little time is available for the doing.
We are not entirely satisfied with
the work of the men who played,
but a word of praise is due them.
The attack showed more positiveness and considerable power. If
we can hold the present team together for three weeks more, further improvement should be manifested.
Barring two occasions
when a cleverly executed shift
fooled the line men, the defensive
line play was excellent. Gettysburg
had a good team. The backs came
hard and fast. We have to thank
our line men for stopping their
progress. The Hopkins back field
men did some wretched tackling.
However, they know their weakness and they will overcome this
with a little practice.
As I have said before, we can't
expect line men to adapt themselves at once to backfield play.
What we like most of all about that
game was the change in the mental
attitude of the men toward the game.
They are beginning to find themselves and to enjoy the game for
the sake of the game. Once this
spirit gets started we are bound to
improve. There is probably nothing more satisfying to a normal
man playing football than the feeling that he has cleaned up the interference or made a good tackle.
It even beats carrying the ball, for
the reason that he knows he has
stopped the other fellow.
Much remains to be done in the
development of the team. The indications now are that we will have
a creditable team at the end of the
season, and we ought not to pass
final judgment until the end of the

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board will
hold its first business meeting at
one o'clock Tuesday in the Trophy
Room. A "dark affair" will be discussed, and the solution of the problem will shape the general policy of
the book. The Board wishes to issue a work "just a little different"
from former numbers, at the same
time preserving the dignity and
cleverness which have been features of some former class volumes.
It is the opinion of many members of the Board that more original stories and features be presented, making place for them by giving up a great deal of space heretofore devoted to class histories,
poems and records.
A member of the Board has suggested that each of the lower classes
be given a certain number of pages
—say eight or ten—which they may
use as they desire; providing, of
course, that their copy is approved
by the Board. In this way the
lower classes may have a closer interest in the book and feel that it
partly belongs to them. The classes
may submit class pictures and histories and any other material that
they think of interest.
Advertising Manager William S.
Merrick reports that forty dollars
in ad contracts have been closed
in the past week, but laments the
fact that freshmen are not showing
an interest in his work. He wants
to get an advertisement from each
of the new men, and to make the
work attractive offers a 20 per cent.
commission. Thus, the man securing a page contract of twenty-five
dollars will receive five' dollars for
his work.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 9, 1914.
MR. KISTLER ON THE FRESHMEN

TECH HAS 70 SCHOLARSHIP MEN

Thinks This Year's Class Has Spirit, but
Says Individual Prowess of Members Is Not Up to Standard.

Third Year of Work Begins With an Enrollment of 120 Men, Over Half of
Whom Hold Free Tuition.

Mr. Kistler, instructor of the

The third year in the Engineering
department begins with an enrollment of one hundred and twenty
students, of whom eighteen are college graduates pursuing graduate
or undergraduate courses. The entering students number eight graduates and fifty undergraduates.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building at Homewood has been completed and is
now occupied, the third-year students receiving there the major portion of their instruction.
Seventy scholarships have been
awarded, sixty of these being provided for by Legislative Act establishing the department. The names
of the appointees are as follows:
STATE SCH0LAR5HIPS-1914-15.

Hopkins gymnasium, has had excellent opportunities in his work to
view some of the idiosyncrasies of
freshmen at first hand and to judge
the merit of individual classes.
The pecularity of freshmen in
general which has struck him most
forcibly is that every year so many
of them are found who have neglected to utilize the advantages of
their preparatory school gymnasiums. • To use his own words:
"Freshmen who have neglected
their gymnasium work in high
school call to mind the boy who
looked for a job with a prayer book
under his arm to help him pray he
wouldn't get it. They have regarded gym as something which
they know they ought to take, but
which they might take every means
to avoid.". Now, he points out,
they are feeling the effects of avoidmg it.
As regards the Class of 1918,
Mr. Kistler is very enthusiastic. He
is not so especially pleased with
individual prowess — the average
strength being, as a matter of fact,
a little below the freshman average,
bu•t he is very much gratified at
their spirit. "What they. lack in
muscle," he says, "can be built up;
it is the vim and dash that really
count and this class certainly has
spirit."
He declares that the freshmen
have plunged into their work in
the gymnasium with exceptionally
hearty enthusiasm. As an example,
he cites the fact that, although the
men could have been excused when
he was forced to be absent for
the Friends' School-Dunham game,
the entire class volunteered to make
up the time on another day.
Mr. Kistler realizes that the athletic future of the college depends
in a great measure upon the men
who develop in the 1918 class,, and,
although he is forced to admit that
all freshmen "are sometimes very,
very fresh;" he firmly believes that
the present freshmen, when their
time comes, will do their share
toward maintaining the traditions
and standards of Hopkins.
Scrub Football Games.

Graduate Manager G. E. Dorsey
and Manager A. F. Voshell, of the
'Varsity football team, are arranging a schedule of games for the
"scrub" team. Games are being.
sought with local secondary school
and club elevens. These contests
will be held at Homewood when
possible, but, of course, will not conflict with the 'Varsity schedule.
All members of the football
squad, excepting the 'Varsity men,
are eligible for the "scrub" team
and all candidates for the latter are
assured an opportunity to participate in the games.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 9,

Y. M. C. A. CHAPEL SERVICES
DRAW LARGER ATTENDANCE

The organization of the Bible
classes of the University Young
Men's Christian Association are
rapidly nearing completion. Dr.
Swartz's class in "The Difficulties
of the Bible," which has held several meetings at one o'clock on
Thursdays, has a membership of
more than twenty men. Dr.
Hogue's class meets also on Thursdays at one o'clock. Mr. Addison's
class meets on Thursdays at 1.15
o'clock. The freshman class is
divided into two sections, one of
which meets on Fridays at one
o'clock. The other holds its meetings at ten o'clock on Thursdays.
A general invitation is still extended by the Association to every
member of the University to join
one of these classes.
The attendance at the chapel
services has been very encouraging,
perhaps more so than that of the
previous year. The Association,
however, is striving to increase
the interest of the student body in
these religious meetings. Dr. Ferris
of Mount Vernon Place M. E.
Church was leader last week. His
services were unusually edifying.
The Association feels a deep gratitude to all those who, like Dr. Ferris, have consented to conduct the
services. A quartet will lead the
singing from now on. This musical addition has been a new feature
during the last couple of weeks.
Dr. J. H. Latane is leader for
this week.
Mr. Willis, a graduate student,
'who has charge of a class in English at the City Jail, gave a very
interesting report of the work.
There are more than thirty men in
his class, which includes mostly illiterates and foreigners. In a general way they may be divided into
four groups: those who do not
know the English alphabet; those
who can read, but cannot spell;
those who can spell, but cannot
read; and, finally, those who have
only a limited knowledge of spelling and reading. Mr. Willis finds
the method of instruction very
simple, and emphasizes the fact
that the work is very interesting
and instructive. For, example, he
finds a peculiar satisfaction and
pleasure in observing the progress
of the members of his class from
lesson to „lesson.
The organization of similar classes
at the Fayette Street M. E. Church
has been unavoidably delayed.
However, this delay is only temporary, and in a short time the
classes will meet regularly. P.
Hayes and A. S. Niles, Jr., will
have charge of two of these classes.

November 7, 1914.
THE NEWS-LETTER:
Editor
of
the
To
SIR—An uncensored letter received by me last week speaks in
glowing terms of the ever-increasing spirit of nationalism prevalent
in England.
Even in the realm of literature a
strong anti-Teutonic sentiment is
felt. The English poets are being
read as never before, the works of
Chaucer in particular having met
with unusual popularity. A friend
of mine has sent me the following
from London:
Whan that the Kiser and his Bisy Bertha
With heeps of deed have covered al the
erthe,
And everich veyne doth flow with raging
blood,
Enough to mak an honest yoman wood,—
Whan Boreas eke with his colde breeth
Y-frozen bath on every bolt and heeth
The rawe recruites, and the only sonne
Of mony a moder bath his spurs y-wonne, .
Whyl bolde fooles maken war-copye
To sellen for a monthly salarye,—
(This is to seyn, they ernen humble gage
By sending dope for many a lying page,)
Than longen plaine folk for pryces lowe
(For meet is hyer, as ye ful wel knowe,)
And eke right plaine the sentence that I
mene is,—
Their hertes pinen for some pork and benes,
Or many anothre dishe that they did love
Before thise sely prices Bored above.
0 cursed prices, welles of iniquitee
Thou movest wrong, lyke primum mobile,
And forcest us the olde sawe to telle,—
How Sherman sayde y-wis that war was
belle.

Yours,
GEOFFREY.

A Suggestion for The News-Letter.

November 6, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—I have long thought that
THE NEWS-LETTER could become
far more useful than it now is if,
departing a bit from its policy, it
would devote more space to articles
like that on Sidney Lanier, or, if
I may be permitted to say so, to
other things besides freshman class
meetings, appeals for support to
the Musical Clubs and football
stories.
In 'the last issue a letter from
Mr. Charles A. Bastin expresses
this view, and it is for the purpose
of elaborating on it that I am now
writing.
First of all, I want to make it
clear that I agree that all stories of
student activities should be printed
in full. THE NEWS-LETTER is an
undergraduate organ, and I do not
desire that a whit less prominence
be given to articles devoted to the
student affairs..
But I believe that there are a
great many subscribers who desire
something further. They want to
know a little of what is going on
in the seminaries; they are interested in research problems being conducted by graduate students, and
they would like to hear the views
of members of the faculty on current subjects from time to time.
The article on Sidney Lanier was
a step in the right direction, and I
suggest that there be similar ones
in coming issues.
Yours very truly,
SENOR GUREZ.

November 5, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—Each week there has appeared in your Mail Bag a poem
about the war. All of them to date
have been in sympathy with the
Allies. I write this letter calling
upon those in the University having pro-German feeling to get to
work and send in verses in support
of the under-dog cause. I am a
friend of Germany and her cause,
and want to see the nation get support, even in the columns of THE
NEWS-LETTER.
Very truly yours,
A FRIEND OF THE KAISER.

What Lanier Articles Have Suggested.

number of letters commending
the articles on Sidney Lanier which
appeared in a previous issue have
keen received by THE NEws-LETTER, and, as they are too long to
print, we acknowledge them here,
at the same time thanking the
writers.
In several of the letters suggestions were made that we continue
to present articles of that character,
for, as it was said, they are more
interesting than the usual "stories"
on sports and other activities. In
reply, it may be pointed out that
THE NEWS-LETTER is, as its name
indicates, a paper devoted primarily
to college news. Its editors are
charged with the duty of collecting
and publishing facts concerning the
activities and problems in which the
Hopkins undergraduates are engaged. To transgress into the field
of the magazine, then, is not strictly
in accordance with the function and
policy of the paper. The Lanier
articles were published because
there was news value in the fact
that it was just 35 years ago that
the poet came to Hopkins.
We believe, however, that occasional articles similar to those on
Lanier would help toward a better
knowledge of the University and
of the men who made its past a brilliant one, and we shall present from
time to time a "magazine page" of
stories of the men who figured in
the establishment and building up
of the University.
The discussion raised by the letters we received brings out the facts
that Hopkins is without a student

magazine and that it has no memorial society.
Princeton, Harvard, Yale, Boston "Tech" and a number of the
colleges with larger student bodies
have monthly magazines devoted to
articles of a literary nature which
can not rightly be printed in their
college newspapers. Of course, a
large student body and a host of
loyal alumni are needed for the support of such an enterprise, and only
those colleges having students and
graduates numbering in the thousands can issue such a book. It is
perhaps too early yet for Hopkins
undergraduates to attempt such a
publication, but it is an activity that
we believe will flourish in years to
come. Imagine The Homewood
Magazine! Happy the men who
will be its editors!
But if Hopkins can not have a
magazine, it can have a society of
those students who are slightly or
wholly antiquarian—students who
want to keep bright and untarnished
the memory of the men who conceived and launched the Universit)
and of those who have been distinguished figures in its history.
This would be a memorial society.
It could hold monthly meetings at
which papers could be read on
Johns Hopkins, Gilman, Lanier,
Sylvester, Rowland and other members of the early faculty. The
meetings could be addressed by
men who knew Hopkins, Lanier,
Gilman and the other leaders in the
early University. A true Hopkins
spirit includes some detailed knowledge of these men.
Membership should be open to
all students paying a small due, and
the accumulation of these dues
could be devoted to the preservation.
of the papers, libraries and other
pertinent effects of the old faculty'
and to the erection of memorials.
Of course, the society could not
do much in its earlier years. It
would have to have prestige (which
means age) before it could be influential. And would it not be appropriate to make this pioneer start
now—just at a time when the University is leaving the buildings
which housed it from its founding
in 1876? The new site on the
bright, large estate at Homewood
will soon cause the old buildings to
be forgotten, and there should be
some means of preserving in photograph and in story the old associations, so that in generations to come
something definite and complete
will be known about the old University. A hundred years from
now loyal sons of Hopkins will
want to know about the buildings
on Monument street. And another
cause in which the society could interest itself would be the erection
of a stone on the grave of Sidney
Lanier in Greenmount Cemetery,
and the placing of a larger memorial to him in the University.
It would certainly not be improper to organize such a society
now, so that the next generation
of students may enjoy an established prestige which will be made
in the next few years.

The freshmen are extremely fortunate this year in the possession
of what promises to be a very successful class football team. Several men from the 'Varsity squad,
including many first-string players,
are expected to come out for the
team. In addition to these men,
there are many in the class whose
work prevents them from playing
regularly, but who expect to come
out when the team begins its practice.
In a class meeting on Wednesday, Burrough was elected manager, and it was decided to have
the captain elected by the team. In
addition to the sophomore game, arrangements will probably be made
with the permission of Head Coach
Cates of the 'Varsity, to play one
or two of the local preparatory
schools, such as City College, Gilman, or Dunham's.
Layfield's position at quarterback
will be a hard one to fill, but the
freshmen are looking to two or
three new men, who, with Mealy,
will compete for this place. A
summary of the material is as follows:

• Claude Uhler was selected senior
delegate to the Athletic Board at
its meeting Monday to fill the vacancy made by the resignation of
William A. Baker, Jr.
A rule of the Student Council
prohibits membership on the Athletic Board and the Student Council at the same time, and as Baker
was elected to both, it was necessary for him to retire from one of
the positions. He chose to serve
the Student Council, and was elected its president. His resignation
from the Athletic Board was accepted Monday, and Uhler was
chosen to take his place.
Advisers for the spring teams
were also officially chosen at the
meeting. The Board ratified the
selections of the following advisers:
For Baseball—Dr. R. B. Roulston and Mr. Dobbin.
For Track—Theodore E. Straus
and J. England.
For Lacrosse—William Schmeisser. Another delegate to be chosen.
The advisers were elected by
committees composed of the managers and captains of the teams,
with Graduate Manager G. E.
Dorsey serving as the third member of each committee.
Assistant managers for spring
teams were also selected. The
Board, however, was disappointed
at the small number of applications

The condition of Bob Layfield,
the 'Varsity quarterback, who was
injured in the Lehigh game Saturday a week ago, has not improved.
He is a critical condition, and while
the surgeons at Johns Hopkins Hospital hope he may recover, they are
not optimistic over his condition.
His backbone is fractured, and an
operation to relieve resulting pressure on the spinal cord is impossible. Layfield is paralyzed from
the neck down.
The case is very similar to that
of Earl Wilson, the Naval Academy player, whose injury several
years ago attracted national interest
because of his prominence as a
player and the fact that an injury
resulting from football had never
before been so serious.
Bob Layfield, in spite of his condition, is bright, and is fighting hard
to recover. His room ill the hospital is filled with flowers—the
tributes having come from Dean
Griffin, the Lehigh football team,
the freshman and sophomore classes
and other societies and individuals
who are concerned about his case.
President Frank J. Goodnow, of
Hopkins; President Henry S.
Drinker, of Lehigh, and Dean Griffin have called to express their sympathy, but only a few friends have
been admitted to his room. President Drinker came from South
Bethlehem, Pa., where Layfield was
injured, especially to see Mr. and
Mrs. W. R. Layfield, the parents of
the player.
At a special meeting of the Athletic Board last week he was awarded an honorary "H," and the emblem sewed on a sweater was taken
to him by Ben Tappan. He appreciated the award more than anything that has been sent. It represents the goal he was seeking to
reach by his playing with the 'Varsity eleven.
The player was graduated from
Friends' School in Wilmington,
Del., last June. He decided to
study medicine at Johns Hopkins,
and to get the proper preparation
came to the University to take the
degree of bachelor of arts. This
was his freshman year.
At the Wilmington school he was
an all-around athlete in spite of
his light weight. He played end on
the football team, was a basketball
star, and ran for the track team.
A letter from Principal Norris, of
Friends' School, to THE NEws-LETT1;11, says that he was one of the
school's best students and athletes,
and that he was an "exemplary
young man."

Dr. John Calvin French, associate professor of English, was elected honorary president of the senior
class at the third meeting of the
year, held on Friday. He was
chosen on the third ballot. A large
number of candidates were nominated, but scattered votes prevented
the formation of a majority on the
earlier ballots.
Dr. French was notified that the
seniors had paid him the highest
honor in their gift by a committee
Friday afternoon. He expressed
his appreciation and asked to be
called upon for any service the class
may need of him.
President Joseph T. Bartlett, Jr..,
was empowered by the class to appoint a committee to arrange benefits for the Hullabaloo. He chose
a committee consisting of George
Hall, chairman; Rush W. Smith
and Joel Hutzler. These men will
co-operate with Business Manager
Spencer in securing funds for the
..class book.
Mr. Spencer made a short speech
on the Hullabaloo in which he notified the men that all pictures intended for the book should be taken
before Christmas. Individual photographs not made before then will
not find a place in the book unless
special arrangement is made. He
also made his usual appeal for the
payment of class dues.

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.

Hopkins was unable to defeat
Gettysburg on Saturday, but all
things considered, the team played
commendable football. The improvement in general team play
over that displayed in previous
games was distinctly encouraging.
Individually the men played with
more assurance and for the first
time this season we saw indications
of concerted efforts, both on attack
and defence. The improvement was
most gratifying in view of the
many enforced changes in the lineup.
When coaches are reduced to the
necessity of making back field men
out of centre and tackle material
at a week's notice, we must not expect too much in the way of finished
execution. Much has to be done
in the involved game of today, and
little time is available for the doing.
We are not entirely satisfied with
the work of the men who played,
but a word of praise is due them.
The attack showed more positiveness and considerable power. If
we can hold the present team together for three weeks more, further improvement should be manifested.
Barring two occasions
when a cleverly executed shift
fooled the line men, the defensive
line play was excellent. Gettysburg
had a good team. The backs came
hard and fast. We have to thank
our line men for stopping their
progress. The Hopkins back field
men did some wretched tackling.
However, they know their weakness and they will overcome this
with a little practice.
As I have said before, we can't
expect line men to adapt themselves at once to backfield play.
What we like most of all about that
game was the change in the mental
attitude of the men toward the game.
They are beginning to find themselves and to enjoy the game for
the sake of the game. Once this
spirit gets started we are bound to
improve. There is probably nothing more satisfying to a normal
man playing football than the feeling that he has cleaned up the interference or made a good tackle.
It even beats carrying the ball, for
the reason that he knows he has
stopped the other fellow.
Much remains to be done in the
development of the team. The indications now are that we will have
a creditable team at the end of the
season, and we ought not to pass
final judgment until the end of the

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board will
hold its first business meeting at
one o'clock Tuesday in the Trophy
Room. A "dark affair" will be discussed, and the solution of the problem will shape the general policy of
the book. The Board wishes to issue a work "just a little different"
from former numbers, at the same
time preserving the dignity and
cleverness which have been features of some former class volumes.
It is the opinion of many members of the Board that more original stories and features be presented, making place for them by giving up a great deal of space heretofore devoted to class histories,
poems and records.
A member of the Board has suggested that each of the lower classes
be given a certain number of pages
—say eight or ten—which they may
use as they desire; providing, of
course, that their copy is approved
by the Board. In this way the
lower classes may have a closer interest in the book and feel that it
partly belongs to them. The classes
may submit class pictures and histories and any other material that
they think of interest.
Advertising Manager William S.
Merrick reports that forty dollars
in ad contracts have been closed
in the past week, but laments the
fact that freshmen are not showing
an interest in his work. He wants
to get an advertisement from each
of the new men, and to make the
work attractive offers a 20 per cent.
commission. Thus, the man securing a page contract of twenty-five
dollars will receive five' dollars for
his work.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 9, 1914.
MR. KISTLER ON THE FRESHMEN

TECH HAS 70 SCHOLARSHIP MEN

Thinks This Year's Class Has Spirit, but
Says Individual Prowess of Members Is Not Up to Standard.

Third Year of Work Begins With an Enrollment of 120 Men, Over Half of
Whom Hold Free Tuition.

Mr. Kistler, instructor of the

The third year in the Engineering
department begins with an enrollment of one hundred and twenty
students, of whom eighteen are college graduates pursuing graduate
or undergraduate courses. The entering students number eight graduates and fifty undergraduates.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building at Homewood has been completed and is
now occupied, the third-year students receiving there the major portion of their instruction.
Seventy scholarships have been
awarded, sixty of these being provided for by Legislative Act establishing the department. The names
of the appointees are as follows:
STATE SCH0LAR5HIPS-1914-15.

Hopkins gymnasium, has had excellent opportunities in his work to
view some of the idiosyncrasies of
freshmen at first hand and to judge
the merit of individual classes.
The pecularity of freshmen in
general which has struck him most
forcibly is that every year so many
of them are found who have neglected to utilize the advantages of
their preparatory school gymnasiums. • To use his own words:
"Freshmen who have neglected
their gymnasium work in high
school call to mind the boy who
looked for a job with a prayer book
under his arm to help him pray he
wouldn't get it. They have regarded gym as something which
they know they ought to take, but
which they might take every means
to avoid.". Now, he points out,
they are feeling the effects of avoidmg it.
As regards the Class of 1918,
Mr. Kistler is very enthusiastic. He
is not so especially pleased with
individual prowess — the average
strength being, as a matter of fact,
a little below the freshman average,
bu•t he is very much gratified at
their spirit. "What they. lack in
muscle," he says, "can be built up;
it is the vim and dash that really
count and this class certainly has
spirit."
He declares that the freshmen
have plunged into their work in
the gymnasium with exceptionally
hearty enthusiasm. As an example,
he cites the fact that, although the
men could have been excused when
he was forced to be absent for
the Friends' School-Dunham game,
the entire class volunteered to make
up the time on another day.
Mr. Kistler realizes that the athletic future of the college depends
in a great measure upon the men
who develop in the 1918 class,, and,
although he is forced to admit that
all freshmen "are sometimes very,
very fresh;" he firmly believes that
the present freshmen, when their
time comes, will do their share
toward maintaining the traditions
and standards of Hopkins.
Scrub Football Games.

Graduate Manager G. E. Dorsey
and Manager A. F. Voshell, of the
'Varsity football team, are arranging a schedule of games for the
"scrub" team. Games are being.
sought with local secondary school
and club elevens. These contests
will be held at Homewood when
possible, but, of course, will not conflict with the 'Varsity schedule.
All members of the football
squad, excepting the 'Varsity men,
are eligible for the "scrub" team
and all candidates for the latter are
assured an opportunity to participate in the games.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 9,

Y. M. C. A. CHAPEL SERVICES
DRAW LARGER ATTENDANCE

The organization of the Bible
classes of the University Young
Men's Christian Association are
rapidly nearing completion. Dr.
Swartz's class in "The Difficulties
of the Bible," which has held several meetings at one o'clock on
Thursdays, has a membership of
more than twenty men. Dr.
Hogue's class meets also on Thursdays at one o'clock. Mr. Addison's
class meets on Thursdays at 1.15
o'clock. The freshman class is
divided into two sections, one of
which meets on Fridays at one
o'clock. The other holds its meetings at ten o'clock on Thursdays.
A general invitation is still extended by the Association to every
member of the University to join
one of these classes.
The attendance at the chapel
services has been very encouraging,
perhaps more so than that of the
previous year. The Association,
however, is striving to increase
the interest of the student body in
these religious meetings. Dr. Ferris
of Mount Vernon Place M. E.
Church was leader last week. His
services were unusually edifying.
The Association feels a deep gratitude to all those who, like Dr. Ferris, have consented to conduct the
services. A quartet will lead the
singing from now on. This musical addition has been a new feature
during the last couple of weeks.
Dr. J. H. Latane is leader for
this week.
Mr. Willis, a graduate student,
'who has charge of a class in English at the City Jail, gave a very
interesting report of the work.
There are more than thirty men in
his class, which includes mostly illiterates and foreigners. In a general way they may be divided into
four groups: those who do not
know the English alphabet; those
who can read, but cannot spell;
those who can spell, but cannot
read; and, finally, those who have
only a limited knowledge of spelling and reading. Mr. Willis finds
the method of instruction very
simple, and emphasizes the fact
that the work is very interesting
and instructive. For, example, he
finds a peculiar satisfaction and
pleasure in observing the progress
of the members of his class from
lesson to „lesson.
The organization of similar classes
at the Fayette Street M. E. Church
has been unavoidably delayed.
However, this delay is only temporary, and in a short time the
classes will meet regularly. P.
Hayes and A. S. Niles, Jr., will
have charge of two of these classes.

THE NEWS-LETTER:
Editor
of
the
To
SIR—An uncensored letter received by me last week speaks in
glowing terms of the ever-increasing spirit of nationalism prevalent
in England.
Even in the realm of literature a
strong anti-Teutonic sentiment is
felt. The English poets are being
read as never before, the works of
Chaucer in particular having met
with unusual popularity. A friend
of mine has sent me the following
from London:
Whan that the Kiser and his Bisy Bertha
With heeps of deed have covered al the
erthe,
And everich veyne doth flow with raging
blood,
Enough to mak an honest yoman wood,—
Whan Boreas eke with his colde breeth
Y-frozen bath on every bolt and heeth
The rawe recruites, and the only sonne
Of mony a moder bath his spurs y-wonne, .
Whyl bolde fooles maken war-copye
To sellen for a monthly salarye,—
(This is to seyn, they ernen humble gage
By sending dope for many a lying page,)
Than longen plaine folk for pryces lowe
(For meet is hyer, as ye ful wel knowe,)
And eke right plaine the sentence that I
mene is,—
Their hertes pinen for some pork and benes,
Or many anothre dishe that they did love
Before thise sely prices Bored above.
0 cursed prices, welles of iniquitee
Thou movest wrong, lyke primum mobile,
And forcest us the olde sawe to telle,—
How Sherman sayde y-wis that war was
belle.

Yours,
GEOFFREY.

A Suggestion for The News-Letter.

November 6, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—I have long thought that
THE NEWS-LETTER could become
far more useful than it now is if,
departing a bit from its policy, it
would devote more space to articles
like that on Sidney Lanier, or, if
I may be permitted to say so, to
other things besides freshman class
meetings, appeals for support to
the Musical Clubs and football
stories.
In 'the last issue a letter from
Mr. Charles A. Bastin expresses
this view, and it is for the purpose
of elaborating on it that I am now
writing.
First of all, I want to make it
clear that I agree that all stories of
student activities should be printed
in full. THE NEWS-LETTER is an
undergraduate organ, and I do not
desire that a whit less prominence
be given to articles devoted to the
student affairs..
But I believe that there are a
great many subscribers who desire
something further. They want to
know a little of what is going on
in the seminaries; they are interested in research problems being conducted by graduate students, and
they would like to hear the views
of members of the faculty on current subjects from time to time.
The article on Sidney Lanier was
a step in the right direction, and I
suggest that there be similar ones
in coming issues.
Yours very truly,
SENOR GUREZ.

All "Poems" Will Be Welcome.

November 5, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—Each week there has appeared in your Mail Bag a poem
about the war. All of them to date
have been in sympathy with the
Allies. I write this letter calling
upon those in the University having pro-German feeling to get to
work and send in verses in support
of the under-dog cause. I am a
friend of Germany and her cause,
and want to see the nation get support, even in the columns of THE
NEWS-LETTER.
Very truly yours,
A FRIEND OF THE KAISER.

doctor.

gwine to take it," and Rastus
shuffled out.—Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch.

What Lanier Articles Have Suggested.

number of letters commending
the articles on Sidney Lanier which
appeared in a previous issue have
keen received by THE NEws-LETTER, and, as they are too long to
print, we acknowledge them here,
at the same time thanking the
writers.
In several of the letters suggestions were made that we continue
to present articles of that character,
for, as it was said, they are more
interesting than the usual "stories"
on sports and other activities. In
reply, it may be pointed out that
THE NEWS-LETTER is, as its name
indicates, a paper devoted primarily
to college news. Its editors are
charged with the duty of collecting
and publishing facts concerning the
activities and problems in which the
Hopkins undergraduates are engaged. To transgress into the field
of the magazine, then, is not strictly
in accordance with the function and
policy of the paper. The Lanier
articles were published because
there was news value in the fact
that it was just 35 years ago that
the poet came to Hopkins.
We believe, however, that occasional articles similar to those on
Lanier would help toward a better
knowledge of the University and
of the men who made its past a brilliant one, and we shall present from
time to time a "magazine page" of
stories of the men who figured in
the establishment and building up
of the University.
The discussion raised by the letters we received brings out the facts
that Hopkins is without a student

magazine and that it has no memorial society.
Princeton, Harvard, Yale, Boston "Tech" and a number of the
colleges with larger student bodies
have monthly magazines devoted to
articles of a literary nature which
can not rightly be printed in their
college newspapers. Of course, a
large student body and a host of
loyal alumni are needed for the support of such an enterprise, and only
those colleges having students and
graduates numbering in the thousands can issue such a book. It is
perhaps too early yet for Hopkins
undergraduates to attempt such a
publication, but it is an activity that
we believe will flourish in years to
come. Imagine The Homewood
Magazine! Happy the men who
will be its editors!
But if Hopkins can not have a
magazine, it can have a society of
those students who are slightly or
wholly antiquarian—students who
want to keep bright and untarnished
the memory of the men who conceived and launched the Universit)
and of those who have been distinguished figures in its history.
This would be a memorial society.
It could hold monthly meetings at
which papers could be read on
Johns Hopkins, Gilman, Lanier,
Sylvester, Rowland and other members of the early faculty. The
meetings could be addressed by
men who knew Hopkins, Lanier,
Gilman and the other leaders in the
early University. A true Hopkins
spirit includes some detailed knowledge of these men.
Membership should be open to
all students paying a small due, and
the accumulation of these dues
could be devoted to the preservation.
of the papers, libraries and other
pertinent effects of the old faculty'
and to the erection of memorials.
Of course, the society could not
do much in its earlier years. It
would have to have prestige (which
means age) before it could be influential. And would it not be appropriate to make this pioneer start
now—just at a time when the University is leaving the buildings
which housed it from its founding
in 1876? The new site on the
bright, large estate at Homewood
will soon cause the old buildings to
be forgotten, and there should be
some means of preserving in photograph and in story the old associations, so that in generations to come
something definite and complete
will be known about the old University. A hundred years from
now loyal sons of Hopkins will
want to know about the buildings
on Monument street. And another
cause in which the society could interest itself would be the erection
of a stone on the grave of Sidney
Lanier in Greenmount Cemetery,
and the placing of a larger memorial to him in the University.
It would certainly not be improper to organize such a society
now, so that the next generation
of students may enjoy an established prestige which will be made
in the next few years.

Freshman Football Candidates.

The freshmen are extremely fortunate this year in the possession
of what promises to be a very successful class football team. Several men from the 'Varsity squad,
including many first-string players,
are expected to come out for the
team. In addition to these men,
there are many in the class whose
work prevents them from playing
regularly, but who expect to come
out when the team begins its practice.
In a class meeting on Wednesday, Burrough was elected manager, and it was decided to have
the captain elected by the team. In
addition to the sophomore game, arrangements will probably be made
with the permission of Head Coach
Cates of the 'Varsity, to play one
or two of the local preparatory
schools, such as City College, Gilman, or Dunham's.
Layfield's position at quarterback
will be a hard one to fill, but the
freshmen are looking to two or
three new men, who, with Mealy,
will compete for this place. A
summary of the material is as follows:
Backs—Ellicott, Duncan, Thurman, Mealy, Hoffman, Connolly,
